transcripts.text: What is the difference between the British SBS and the American Navy SEALs?  And who's best?

Well, you know what?  I always say about the British military being the best in the world because we haven't got any money.  So we're jack of all trades, masters of none.  But one thing I'll say, at the end of the day, when it comes to the SBS and the SEALs, I just think we have a bigger toolbox.  You know, we're good at a number of different skills.  Fortunately, the Americans do have a lot more money or budget for the military so that when it comes to, you know, they'll get one person to hold the rifle and the other person to pull the trigger.  But, you know, I just, sorry, but whether you call me biased or what, I just think the SBS are absolutely amazing.  And I'll put them at the top of the pedestal any day.

Well, I... was talking to somebody the other day, SBS, and they said they hadn't done the dive course, which I was really surprised about.  They'd gone straight out to the Middle East, basically.  and they started the dive but hadn't finished it.  I was really...

Yeah, I think a lot of that, that's just because of circumstances, isn't it?  I think there's quite a lot of people that they join the SBS and because of the demand out in Afghan and various other theatres, I just don't think they had time to do that.  So although they joined the SBS... And, you know, it is quite a specialist skill, the SBS.  It's not to say we don't, you know, we obviously can do everything we do on land anyway, but our specialist skill is waterborne operations and insertion operations.  But in a theater that's not demanding that, then what are you going to do?  Stick people on a dive course or get them out into the war zone as quickly as possible to support the other lads.  So I think that was just circumstantial.  And I certainly know there's a few people saying, Yeah, no, I think you're exactly right.

And just the two last questions, Ollie, just from a physical perspective, for those of us that have found our physical prime at 50 years old, what's kind of the hardest like running type or marching type event you do?  And what's the kind of hardest swimming or diving event?

The hardest part, and I don't know if they do it so much before, because not many people know this, but I think I'm one of three people in the world that has done the old SBS selection and the new SAS selection.  So I did my first selection, got to the end, and there was a bit of an altercation with the Welsh farmer on the combat and survival, which meant that I got RTU'd at the last moment.  And when I went back, that was the old special boat SBS selection, which was we used to join with Hereford for the trees and also combat survival at the end.  But the rest was sort of done individually.  So then I went back after.
Is that the jungle, the trees?

Yeah, the jungle, sorry, yeah.  And then when I went back, it was the first, I did the second course, I missed the first one, I did the second course of the new selection, which is the joint selection.  But on the first selection, we used to do a thing called a portage, which is nine miles with a clepper canoe.  And that, I mean, we've actually got it coming up in SAS.  Who Dares Wins in the next, I don't think it's, I don't know if it's tonight's on Monday or whether it's next week, but it's coming up anyway.  But basically that is where you split the, you know, the bones of the canoe.  It's a two man military canoe, a Klepper, that you take all the bones out, which is the wood parts.  Someone carries that and someone else carries the skin.  And you had to carry that for nine miles.  I think that's, that's probably the hardest march I've ever done because the weight was just insane, insane amount of weight on your shoulders.  Um, and then what was it?  The swimming was the other question about, um, to be honest, you didn't, I mean, you had to be a good swimmer, but really, you know, it's, it's, it's, Showing a level of swimming ability when you're on selection.  I mean, the hardest swims we did was surface swims when we actually joined the SBS.  You know what I mean?  You would do a few K surface swim.  And also, you know, some of the ops dives you did, you know, some of the, you know, you only use diving in the SBS as a means of transport, as a means of transit.  You know, three meters below the surface thereabouts on a rebreather at night usually.  just following the compass board to target.  And some of those were absolutely hideous, but the surface, you know, subsurface was actually easier than doing surface swims.  You know, you do 5K surface swim, it's just hideous, hideous.
Is this where you've come up to the surface in your dive gear and you're finning, say, a shore?  Yeah.

Yeah, that's, that's correct.  And you can have, or, you know, you, you could be swimming out to a target or for extraction, you could be swimming into target.  Um, and you could more than likely have an ops bag as well.  So you'd have like a, an Ortlieb bag with all your ops kit in there.  And, um, you know, sometimes, you know, you're swimming, you're just stationary because you're swimming against the tide and you just got to swim against the tide until the tide changes or, or becomes high tide or low tide before you can carry on.  So it's just horrendous, hideous.  I found that hideous more than going subsurface.  Wow.
